title: Baseline Grid
content:
So in school they teach us how to set type, but they dont teach you how to use the programs.

Cut the rambling short, what is the base line grid, and what do I use it for?

Ive scoured the internet which brings up a bunch of crap.

Im sure most of you typophiles out there know how to utilize it. I would love any insightful information.

Cheers

James
author: James Scriven

comments.content:
Rather than the position of the baseline being determined in relation to a text box, baseline grid determines it in relation to the page, and, when it's on, overides any leading value applied within text boxes.

It's a good way to get the type in adjacent columns to line up with one another.

If you set 9/10, but the grid is 14, you get 9/14. If you set 9/14.5, you get 9/28.

A good trick is to set the grid to half your leading. That way you can do stuff like applying extra between-paragraph leading with a value equal to the baseline grid.

These may help if you're using InDesign:

[http://www.tek-tips.com/viewthread.cfm?qid=1274288&page=1](http://web.archive.org/web/20131020211350/http:/www.tek-tips.com/viewthread.cfm?qid=1274288&page=1 "http://www.tek-tips.com/viewthread.cfm?qid=1274288&page=1")

[http://www.nhodge.com/mn8/article/470/](http://web.archive.org/web/20131020211350/http:/www.nhodge.com/mn8/article/470/ "http://www.nhodge.com/mn8/article/470/")

(James, it's quite debatable whether you are actually being taught to set type if you're not being taught to use the baseline grid functions for either Indesign or QuarkXpress).

Here are a couple of screenshots from some classes I've done.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20131020211350im_/http:/typophile.com/files/Indy-grid_5635.jpg)
  

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20131020211350im_/http:/typophile.com/files/QXD-grid_6323.jpg)

The second example (from a magazine I worked on in the early 1990s) demonstrates both the second and the last points that Nick makes above – the standfirst paragraph at the top has a leading value that takes the text baselines to every _other_ line of the baseline grid. The adjacent column baselines at the bottom of the picture align perfectly at top and bottom of the column height.

I also often suggest that commonly-recurring negative spaces within a publication (e.g. picture box runarounds, column gutter values and inter-paragraph spacing) are best worked out as multiples of the baseline grid/main text leading value.

There is also a rather scant mention of the baseline grid in a downloadable .pdf tutorial from Computer Arts at  
 [http://www.computerarts.co.uk/tutorials/2d\_\_and\_\_photoshop/editorial\_typ...](http://web.archive.org/web/20131020211350/http:/www.computerarts.co.uk/tutorials/2d __and__ photoshop/editorial_type_design "http://www.computerarts.co.uk/tutorials/2d\_\_and\_\_photoshop/editorial\_type\_design")
